channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Coronavirus Updates: White House Blocks Fauci From Speaking to Congress
item.description: At least 10 states eased restrictions. More than 4,000 workers in U.S. meatpacking plants have been diagnosed with the virus.

item.title: Michigan Governor Reinstates State of Emergency as Protests Ramp Up
item.description: The governor’s moves were in response to the Republican-led Legislature’s refusal to extend the original emergency declaration.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:credit: Nicole Hester/Ann Arbor News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Protesters inside the Capitol building in Lansing, Mich., watched a demonstration outside on Thursday.

item.title: Two Arrested in Killings of Transgender Women in Puerto Rico
item.description: The police said they had classified the deaths as a hate crime after the remains of two women were found in a badly burned car last week.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson and Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:description: The Facebook profile photo of Serena Angelique Velázquez, one of two transgender women killed last week in Puerto Rico.

item.title: Gavin Newsom Orders Orange County Beaches Closed Due to Coronavirus
item.description: Images of packed shores have prompted a furor against officials in coastal states like California and Florida, who have resisted statewide beach closure orders.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei, Shawn Hubler and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: People flocked to Huntington Beach, Calif., last weekend despite advice that they keep their distance from one another to limit the spread of the coronavirus.

item.title: Doctor Who Promoted Malarial Drug Draws Scrutiny of Federal Prosectors
item.description: In an interview, Dr. Vladimir Zelenko said he was guilty of nothing more than sloppy wording.
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere and Kevin Roose
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Bryan Derballa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Vladimir Zelenko proposed treating the coronavirus with a three-drug cocktail of hydroxychloroquine, azithromycin and zinc after seeing numerous patients with Covid-19 symptoms in upstate New York.

item.title: Harvard Kept Ties With Jeffrey Epstein After ’08 Conviction, Report Shows
item.description: A university review found that the disgraced financier, who killed himself last year, visited Harvard more than 40 times after he was convicted of sex charges involving a minor in Florida.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Tristan Spinski for The New York Times
item.media:description: Harvard University’s campus in March.

item.title: Is It Safe to Come Out of Lockdown? Check the Sewer
item.description: Wastewater could provide early, painless and localized data about the rise or fall of coronavirus levels.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: Researchers from Brazil’s National Institute of Science and Technology collected sewage samples to test for coronavirus in Belo Horizonte last month.

item.title: Drive-Throughs Are Now a Lifeline for Fast-Food Chains
item.description: With dine-in restaurants shuttered and social distancing paramount, drive-throughs are now providing a crucial source of revenue during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:credit: Leah Frances for The New York Times
item.media:description: While restaurant dining rooms sit empty, many people have started treating drive-throughs like grocery stores, making only occasional trips but placing larger orders.

item.title: The Coronavirus Still Is a Global Health Emergency, W.H.O. Warns
item.description: Even as some governments contemplate reopening, the spread of the virus has accelerated in countries in Africa and South America.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:description: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, director-general of the W.H.O., during a coronavirus press briefing in Geneva in March.

item.title: Coronavirus Drives Signs of a Major Drop in College Enrollment
item.description: Uncertain that campuses will reopen, students are reluctant to commit for the fall. For schools, enrollment drops and lost revenue could be devastating.
item.dc:creator: Anemona Hartocollis and Dan Levin
item.media:credit: Sasha Maslov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tiffany Tang of Albany, N.Y., was choosing from among four schools that had accepted her. This week, three more that had put her on the wait list got in touch.

item.title: The Hunt for Moby Dick Moves Online
item.description: Every year, the New Bedford Whaling Museum hosts a marathon reading of “Moby-Dick.” For the social distancing edition, volunteers are recording performances from home.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:description: “Sperm Whaling — Stove Boat #4,” a painting by an anonymous whaler in the New Bedford Whaling Museum’s collection.

item.title: Blood Pressure Drugs Don’t Increase Coronavirus Risk, Studies Find
item.description: People taking widely used medicines did not face higher rates of infection or more severe illness, new research indicates.
item.dc:creator: Denise Grady
item.media:description: A study published Friday found that ACE inhibitors, ARBs, beta blockers and other commonly used blood pressure drugs do not increase the risk of coronavirus infection, or severe illness as a result of infection.

item.title: Full Transcript: Joe Biden Addresses Tara Reade Allegations on ‘Morning Joe’
item.description: The former vice president was interviewed about the allegation made by his former Senate aide that he sexually assaulted her in 1993.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor and Isabella Grullón Paz
item.media:credit: MSNBC's Morning Joe, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. spoke with Mika Brzezinski on MSNBC on Friday.

item.title: How to Be a Good Neighbor Now
item.description: How we come together when we can’t go very far.
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Picking fruit out of a yard in the Silver Lake neighborhood of Los Angeles.

item.title: A Composer and Her (Very) Long String Instrument
item.description: Ellen Fullman is sheltering in place with the 40-string, 45-foot-long droning instrument she created decades ago.
item.dc:creator: Kerry O’Brien
item.media:credit: Erin Brethauer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Her diary mostly contains tablature notation, but one entry, from before quarantine, last December, reads: “Try to find resonances — textural miracles that are confusing as to structure but spinning and mesmerizing.”

item.title: Coronavirus in California: Newsom Orders Beaches Closed
item.description: Friday: You probably can’t go to the beach. But restrictions on other activities have been loosened. Also: A remembrance, and photos of poppies.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:description: Along California Highway 1 south of Half Moon Bay, people paused to take photos on Thursday at one of the few vista spots that was still open to parking.

item.title: Big Government? For Now, Most Americans Say Bring It On
item.description: Battered by the coronavirus, the American public is increasingly looking to the federal government to provide an economic lifeline, polls suggest.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)

item.title: Coronavirus, Gretchen Whitmer, Joe Biden: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford

item.title: Street Art Confronts the Pandemic
item.description: From Norway to Colorado, street artists depict a world of masks and hand-washing (and toilet paper). One recurrent theme: a deep appreciation of health care workers.
item.dc:creator: Charu Suri
item.media:description: “The Lovers,” by the Norwegian artist Pobel, in Bryne, Norway.

item.title: A Life and Death Battle: 4 Days of Kidney Failure but No Dialysis
item.description: At the peak of the pandemic in New York, a longtime city employee joined a crush of patients in desperate need of treatment.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Kulish

item.title: Find a Vaccine. Next: Produce 300 Million Vials of It.
item.description: Scaling up the manufacturing of syringes and other medical products required to deliver a vaccine to millions of Americans will be just as important as the vaccine itself.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.category: Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority
item.media:credit: Bsip/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Syringes on an assembly line in a pharmaceutical plant in France. Even when a vaccine is developed, producing the number of vials and syringes needed for a coronavirus vaccine will prove a significant hurdle.

item.title: An Accidental Navy Chief Steers His Service Through a Storm
item.description: Adm. Michael M. Gilday appears determined that his recommendations on the Roosevelt case will be made based on Navy principles and not on fears of what the White House might want.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: In recommending the reinstatement of the captain of the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt, Admiral Michael M. Gilday put the Navy before his own career.

item.title: A Crime Novelist on the Oakland County Child Killer Case
item.description: The still-unsolved Oakland County Child Killer case lodged in the author Megan Abbott’s psyche, even if she didn’t know it at the time.
item.dc:creator: Megan Abbott
item.media:description: At an operations center in Beverly Hills, Mich., in March 1977, the police received an avalanche of tips as they worked to find the killer of Timothy King.

item.title: Biden Denies Tara Reade’s Assault Allegation: ‘This Never Happened’
item.description: Joseph R. Biden Jr., in his first public address of a former Senate aide’s accusation that he sexually assaulted her in 1993, called on the National Archives to release any document related to the allegation.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck, Lisa Lerer and Sydney Ember
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign has denied the allegation by Tara Reade, but Mr. Biden did not address it publicly for weeks.

item.title: #CancelRent Is New Rallying Cry for Tenants. Landlords Are Alarmed.
item.description: From New York to Los Angeles, tenant groups are encouraging millions of renters to withhold May rent, which landlords warn would be devastating.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Haag and Conor Dougherty
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Stephen Speranza for The New York Times
item.media:description: A banner in Brooklyn promoting a rent strike on May 1.

item.title: Anderson Cooper Announces Birth of Son Wyatt
item.description: Wyatt Morgan Cooper, who is named after the newscaster’s late father, was delivered by a surrogate.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: “I am a dad,” Mr. Cooper said. “I have a son, and I want you to meet him.”

item.title: World Coronavirus Tracker: Britain, India, China
item.description: The W.H.O. extends the global health emergency as deaths near 240,000, and our New Delhi correspondent paints a portrait of a fearful city.
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: IFLb, an independent laboratory in Berlin, conducting tests for SARS-CoV-2 on samples sent by hospitals. Blood samples are critical for the development of vaccines, cures, treatments and tests for diseases.

item.title: U.S. Stocks End the Week Lower After Tech Earnings: Live Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A demonstration near an Amazon warehouse on Staten Island called for more workplace protections during the pandemic.

item.title: Labs Across U.S. Join Federal Initiative to Study Coronavirus Genome
item.description: The project, announced by the C.D.C., will help trace patterns of transmission, investigate outbreaks and map how the virus is evolving, which can affect a cure.
item.dc:creator: Sheri Fink
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Virus particles, marked in blue, that were taken from an early Covid-19 patient in the U.S.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Public beaches have become a flashpoint as the U.S. begins to emerge from stay-at-home restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Patrick J. Lyons

item.title: Oprah Winfrey to Give Commencement Address on Facebook
item.description: Oprah Winfrey will give a virtual commencement address on Facebook for college and high school seniors across the United States.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: It will be a busy season for Oprah Winfrey, who has also agreed to be an online commencement speaker for all high schools in Chicago.

item.title: Peter Hunt, Who Directed the Broadway Hit ‘1776,’ Dies at 81
item.description: The musical about the founding fathers, his Broadway directorial debut, scored three Tonys. He was also a mainstay of the Williamstown Theater Festival.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger

item.title: Scrambling the Political Divide: ‘No Normal Recession’
item.description: When a Republican senator shops a stimulus plan that has more common ground with a leading progressive.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:description: Senator Josh Hawley of Missouri.

item.title: Democrats Assail Mitch McConnell for Bringing Senate Back Amid Pandemic
item.description: The majority leader’s plan to reconvene next week carries dangers for lawmakers as well as workers at the Capitol, where many low-level employees are minorities and at greater risk from Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:description: Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, last week. “If people on the front lines are willing to work during the pandemic, we should be as well,” he told Fox News Radio this week.

item.title: Amid a Rising Coronavirus Death Toll, Trump Leaves the Grieving to Others
item.description: President Trump has led no national mourning for the more than 63,000 Americans who have died from the coronavirus, emphasizing confidence about the future rather than dwelling on the present.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Trump appears reluctant to talk about the 63,000 people who have died from the coronavirus in the United States.

item.title: After Decades of Service, Five Nuns Die as Virus Sweeps Through Convent
item.description: The coronavirus outbreak was difficult to trace in the Wisconsin convent, which specializes in care for aging nuns with dementia.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman
item.category: Our Lady of the Angels Convent (Greenfield, Wis)

item.title: Trump Attacks Flynn Inquiry Amid New Revelations on F.B.I.
item.description: The bureau was on the verge of closing its investigation into Michael Flynn in early 2017 when new evidence prompted agents to keep it open, newly disclosed court papers showed.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s onetime national security adviser, has backtracked on his guilty plea to the F.B.I. and fought the criminal case against him.
